title: AMC Marks a Record  For Labor Day Period  ----  By Maria Armental
text:
Marvel Studios' "Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings" had a record debut that drove the best Labor Day weekend attendance figures at AMC Theatres, the chain's parent company said Tuesday.

AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc., the parent company of the theater chain, said that more than two million people watched movies at its U.S. theaters Thursday through Sunday, which the company considers the Labor Day weekend, and about 800,000 at its European and Middle East locations.

The weekend's results mark milestones for the company, which like others in the entertainment sector had been hit hard by pandemic-related restrictions to help curb the spread of Covid-19.

"This is the very first weekend that our attendance numbers were ahead of those of the same weekend pre-pandemic, since we closed our theaters in March of 2020," Chief Executive Adam Aron said. He also said that admissions revenue broke its 2013 record for Labor Day weekend in the U.S.

AMC's shares jumped 8.7% in Tuesday trading to $47.83. The stock started the year at about $2 a share.

Walt Disney Co.'s "Shang-Chi," which stars Simu Liu as Shang-Chi, opened only in theaters to a reported $90 million in the U.S. and Canada, according to industry estimates.

The second-highest-grossing film for the weekend, Universal Pictures' horror film "Candyman," took in an estimated $13.4 million.

Across North America, films released over the Labor Day weekend were expected to bring in nearly $135 million for the four-day period, according to media-measurement firm Comscore.
